block.p: ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. ''Romantic Outsider: The Films of Alan Rudolph,'' begins tomorrow and runs through May 28. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., ''Choose Me'' (1984); at 4:15 p.m., ''Welcome to L. A'' (1976). Sunday at 2 p.m., ''Remember My Name'' (1978); at 4 p.m., ''Trouble in Mind'' (1985). Martin Scorsese's ''Goodfellas'' (1990), tonight and tomorrow night at 6:30, Evening screenings, $8; $4 for members and the elderly. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, noon to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. All activities are free with museum admission unless otherwise indicated. Admission: $8.50; the elderly and students, $5.50; ages 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and under, free. Information: (718) 784-0077.
ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. ''Romantic Outsider: The Films of Alan Rudolph,'' begins tomorrow and runs through May 28. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., ''Choose Me'' (1984); at 4:15 p.m., ''Welcome to L. A'' (1976). Sunday at 2 p.m., ''Remember My Name'' (1978); at 4 p.m., ''Trouble in Mind'' (1985). Martin Scorsese's ''Goodfellas'' (1990), tonight and tomorrow night at 6:30, Evening screenings, $8; $4 for members and the elderly. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, noon to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. All activities are free with museum admission unless otherwise indicated. Admission: $8.50; the elderly and students, $5.50; ages 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and under, free. Information: (718) 784-0077.

HISTORIC RICHMONDTOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown. More than 25 buildings from the late 17th to the 19th centuries, restored and furnished. This village and outdoor museum depict the history of Staten Island and the surrounding region. Quilt festival, today through Sunday from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free with village admission. The exhibition ''Toys!'' will run through December 2001. Guided tours are available. Wednesdays through Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m.; hours change in July. Admission: $4; the elderly and children 6 to 18, and students, $2.50; 5 and under, free. Information: (718) 351-1611.

LOWER EAST SIDE TENEMENT MUSEUM, 90 Orchard Street, at Broome Street. A look at the urban immigrant experience. The museum includes a partly restored tenement at 97 Orchard Street. ''Firecrackers: Chinatown Today,'' photographic works by Andrew Garn mounted on light boxes; through June 20. Guided tours: Tuesdays through Fridays at 1, 2, 3 and 4 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, every half-hour beginning at 11 a.m. until the last tour at 4:30 p.m. Suggested donation: $3. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, noon to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free. Tour prices: $9; students, the elderly and children over 5, $7; children 5 and under, free. Special prices for two and three tours. Information: (212) 431-0233.

MERCHANT'S HOUSE MUSEUM, 29 East Fourth Street, East Village. This preserved late Federal brick home with a Greek Revival interior, once owned by Seabury Tredwell, a wealthy hardware dealer, was built in 1832. The house holds the original furniture, clothing and personal articles of the Tredwells, who lived there for nearly 100 years. ''Dressmaking in a 19th-Century New York City Town House,'' focusing on the period 1850-75; through May 29. Guided tours are on Saturdays and Sundays; a self-guided tour is available on weekdays. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; students and the elderly, $3; members, free. Information: (212) 777-1089.

MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street. ''New York Now 2000: Contemporary Work in Photography,'' opens tomorrow and runs through Oct. 15. ''Ordinary People, Extraordinary Lives: 100 Years of Labor in New York City,'' a tribute to New York's working people, through July 16. Tomorrow at 1 p.m., ''Marching to Union Square,'' a 45-minute play about the first labor parade in New York City drawn from contemporary speeches and newspaper accounts. Sunday at 1 p.m., a panel discussion with the author Robin Hathaway and Cookie Ziemba, an expert on dollhouses and miniature reproductions. Sunday at 3 p.m., a concert with the singer and musicologist Paula Lockheart and pianist and singer Michael Sansonia exploring 100 years of New York City songs; also at 3 p.m., a gallery talk with the labor activist and working women's historian Connie Kopelov in conjunction with the exhibition ''Ordinary People, Extraordinary Lives: 100 Years of Labor in New York City.'' Hours: Tuesdays, 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. for registered groups only; Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Suggested admission: $7; the elderly, students and children, $4; families, $12. Information: (212) 534-1672.

MUSEUM OF JEWISH HERITAGE: A LIVING MEMORIAL TO THE HOLOCAUST, 18 First Place, at West Street and Battery Place, Battery Park City. Artifacts, documents, photographs, videos and film clips are included in exhibitions on the Holocaust and on Jewish life before and after World War II. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Fridays and the eves of Jewish holidays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; closed Saturdays. Admission: $7; students and the elderly, $5; age 5 and under, free. Tickets can be bought in advance through Ticketmaster, (212) 307-4007, or by calling the museum on the day of the visit, (212) 945-0039. Information: (212) 509-6130.

MUSEUM OF TELEVISION AND RADIO, 25 West 52nd Street, Manhattan. Television Documentary Festival, featuring documentaries produced for television in the United States in the past year, following each screening with a panel discussion involving the audience, filmmaker and production team; through Sunday. Today at 12:15, Biography: ''Brian Wilson: A Beach Boy's Tale.'' Tonight at 6, screening of Biography: ''Sam Phillips: The Man Who Invented Rock 'n' Roll.'' Tomorrow at 2 p.m. and Sunday at 2:30 p.m., ''Nova: Submarines, Secrets and Spies.'' Tomorrow at 4:30 p.m. and Sunday at 12:15 p.m., ''Dying to Tell the Story.'' ''Something for Everyone: Sondheim Tonight,'' a retrospective commemorating the composer's 70th birthday. Daily screenings at 2; additional screenings on Thursdays at 5:30 p.m. and Fridays at 6:30 p.m.; through June 25. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m. On Fridays the theater is open until 9. Admission: $6; students and the elderly, $4; 13 and under, $3. Information: (212) 621-6800.

NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY, 170 Central Park West, near 77th Street. ''Stork Club,'' including an environmental installation that mimics the floor plan of the club, photographs and memorabilia belonging to the family of Sherman Billingsley, the owner of the club; through Oct. 1. ''Magnum, Our Turning World: Photographs, 1989-1999,'' through June 18. ''New York Inside Out,'' an exhibition portraying New Yorkers at home; through Aug. 20. ''Jesse Tarbox Beals: On Assignment,'' photographs, through July 2. ''Without Sanctuary: Lynching Photography in America,'' images from the 1870's through the 1950's, through July 9. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; students and the elderly, $3; 12 and under, free. Information: (212) 873-3400.

SOUTH STREET SEAPORT MUSEUM AND MARKETPLACE, South and Fulton Streets, Lower Manhattan. ''American Tattoo: The Art of Gus Wagner,'' in the Whitman Gallery, through June 11. ''SOS Festival,'' a day with the Coast Guard, learning how to stay safe on the water, all day tomorrow. Free with museum admission; $2 materials fee, at the Children's Center, 165 John Street. Museum hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; closed Tuesdays. Stores in the marketplace: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Sundays, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. Museum admission: $6; the elderly, $5; students, $4; children 12 and under, $3. Information: (212) 748-8600; reservations for special events: (212) 748-8786; the marketplace, (212) 732-7678.
Cruises

CIRCLE LINE CRUISES, leaving from Pier 83, 42nd Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. A two-hour 24-mile cruise around southern Manhattan, passing landmarks like Ellis Island and the United Nations, daily at 11 a.m. and 3:30 p.m. Tickets: $18; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. A three-hour, 35-mile cruise around all of Manhattan, today at 10 a.m., noon, 1:30 and 2:30 p.m.; beginning tomorrow, daily at 9:30 and 10:30 a.m., 12:30, 1:30, 2:30 and 4:30 p.m. Tickets: $22; children 12 and under, $12; the elderly, $19. ''Harbor Lights,'' Fridays through Sundays, 7 p.m. Tickets: $18; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. Information: (212) 563-3200.

WORLD YACHT, leaving from Pier 81, 41st Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. Daily dinner cruises along the West Side of Manhattan and around New York Harbor, from 7 to 10 p.m., boarding at 6 p.m. Prices: Fridays, $75; Saturdays, $79; Sundays, $67 (does not include beverages, taxes or gratuities). Brunch cruises sail on Sundays from 12:30 to 2:30 p.m., with boarding at 11:30 a.m. Price: $39.95. Information: (212) 630-8100.

N.Y. WATERWAY, leaving from Pier 78, West 38th Street and 12th Avenue, Manhattan. Daily two-hour full Manhattan cruise, at 10:30 a.m. and 1:30 p.m., through Nov. 12. Tickets: $24; $19 for the elderly; $12 for children. Daily, a 90-minute cruise of New York Harbor; at 10 a.m., noon, 2 and 4 p.m.; through May 26. Tickets: $19; the elderly, $16; ages 3 to 12, $9; 2 and younger, free. Fridays at 10:15 p.m., Disco cruise. Price: $19; $9 for children. A 70-minute twilight tour leaves daily, except Tuesday, at 8:45 p.m.; additional tours on Saturdays at 7:15 and 10:15 p.m. and on Sundays at 7:15. Tickets: $19; the elderly, $16; children, $9. Information: (800) 533-3779.
Gardens

BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN, 900 Washington Avenue, Prospect Heights. More than 12,000 kinds of plants from around the world are displayed on 52 acres. ''Cherry Watch 2000,'' through May, the blooming of the cherry trees. Exhibition of Oriental brush paintings through Sunday in the Steinhardt Conservatory Gallery. In late May the bluebells are in bloom on a wooded slope of the garden. The Japanese Garden reopens Tuesday after a 33-month restoration project; through June 18. Gallery hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $3; $1.50 for students and the elderly; free for children 15 and under; free on Tuesdays, except holidays; and free from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. The conservatory closes 30 minutes before the grounds close. Information: (718) 623-7200.

NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN, 200th Street and Kazimiroff Boulevard, Fordham, the Bronx. The grounds include 27 specialty gardens and plant collections and a 40-acre forest. The azaleas, dogwoods and lilacs are at peak bloom. The Rock Garden, home to thousands of alpine plants from six continents, is in bloom through mid-June. The Chinese Peony Show is through June 4 in the Haupt Conservatory, with the tree peonies in bloom; featuring lectures, demonstrations and workshops. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., lecture on Chinese healing; Sunday at 2 p.m., lecture on the effect of Chinese horticulture on the West in the 18th and 19th centuries. Garden hours: Tuesdays through Sundays and Monday holidays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Conservatory admission: $3.50; students and the elderly, $2.50; children 2 to 12, $2; under 2, free. Grounds admission free for all on Wednesdays and from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. There are also combination packages. Parking: $5. A ''garden passport'' combination ticket grants admission to the entire grounds, with a tram tour: adults, $10; students and the elderly, $7.50; children 2 to 12, $4; under 2, free. Information: (718) 817-8700.

STATEN ISLAND BOTANICAL GARDEN, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. The garden covers 83 acres, with neo-Classical buildings that once housed retired seamen. Hours: daily, dawn to dusk. Free admission to the grounds. The one-acre New York Chinese Scholar's Garden is open. ''China: Ancient Art and Sciences,'' featuring 13 artisans from China demonstrating their craft and 300 works of art; through Oct. 1. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission to the Chinese Scholar's Garden: $7.50; $5 for the elderly and students and children under 12; under 1, free. Information: (718) 273-8200.

WAVE HILL, West 249th Street and Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx. Gardens, greenhouses and woodlands are part of the 28-acre garden and cultural institution. Landscape paintings of China by Manshen Wang are on exhibition through Sunday. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., ''Soul Food in the Sund,'' with Barbara Connell demonstrating how to cook peach cobbler, collard greens and sweet potato pie. Tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m., ''Get the Gourds Growing,'' activities and songs with Yvette Martinez and turning a planting of a gourd patch into a party. Sunday at 2 p.m., an adult craft workshop on herbs useful for promoting sleep, Tuesdays through Sundays, 9 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; Saturdays, free until noon. Information: (718) 549-3200; reservations: extension 213.
Zoos

BRONX ZOO, Bronx River Parkway and Fordham Road, Fordham. Some 265 wooded acres are devoted to naturalistic habitats, including Jungle World, African Plains, the Baboon Reserve, the World of Birds, the Aitken Sea Bird Colony (with daily penguin feedings at 3:30 p.m., weather permitting), Big Birds and the Congo Gorilla Forest. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission $9; $5 for children 2 to 12 and the elderly; free for everyone on Wednesdays. Parking: $6. Information: (718) 367-1010.
ON THE STREET
FEAST OF ST. ANTHONY, Mott Street, from Hester to Canal Streets, Little Italy. Daily, 2 to 11:30 p.m., through May 29. Sponsored by the St. Anthony Society and Most Precious Blood Church.

''EARTH CELEBRATIONS' RITES OF SPRING: PROCESSION TO SAVE OUR GARDENS,'' Lower Manhattan. An eight-hour pageant with music and dance that passes more than 30 gardens. Begins tomorrow at 10 a.m. at Forsyth Street, between Broome and Delancey Streets.

FINANCIAL COMMUNITY DAY FAIR, Beaver Street, from Whitehall to Pearl Streets, Lower Manhattan. A tribute to Wall Street, with crafts, exhibits and food. Today, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by Chabad of Wall Street.
YE OLDE VILLAGE FAIR, Bedford, Barrow and Commerce Streets, West Village. Tomorrow, 11 a.m to 10 p.m. Sponsored by the Bedford Barrow Commerce Block Association.
TURKISH AMERICAN PARADE, Manhattan. Begins tomorrow at 2 p.m. at Madison Avenue and 55th Street and heads south to 47th Street, turning east to First Avenue.
27TH NINTH AVENUE INTERNATIONAL FOOD FESTIVAL, Ninth Avenue, from 37th to 57th Streets, Manhattan. Tomorrow and Sunday, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.
STREET FAIR, Columbia Grammar and Preparatory School, 94th Street, between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue, Manhattan. Tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.
MARTIN LUTHER KING JR. PARADE, Manhattan. Sunday at noon on Fifth Avenue, from 60th to 86th Streets.
AMSTERDAM AVENUE STREET FAIR, from 77th to 92d Streets, Manhattan. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.
EVENTS

''YOU GOTTA HAVE PARK! 2000,'' Prospect Park, various sites, Brooklyn. Annual celebration with clean-up activities, nature tours, rides and entertainment. Tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sunday noon to 8 p.m. Donation, $1. Sponsored by the Prospect Park Alliance and the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation. Information: (718) 965-8999.

ANNUAL PARK SLOPE CIVIC COUNCIL HOUSE TOUR, Brooklyn. A self-guided tour featuring eight turn-of-the-century homes. Sunday, noon to 5 p.m. Fee, $15 in advance, $20 on Sunday. Tickets available at Congregation Beth Elohim, Eighth Avenue at Garfield Place. Information: (718) 832-8227.

SIXTH NEW YORK INTERNATIONAL TRIBAL ANTIQUES SHOW, Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 67th Street, Manhattan. Opening night benefit tomorrow at 6 p.m. Tickets, $75; proceeds benefit the Gay Men's Health Crisis. Show hours: Sunday, noon to 7 p.m.; Monday and Tuesday, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Wednesday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission, $15. Information: (212) 472-1180.
WALKING TOURS

''BIZARRE AND ECCENTRIC EAST VILLAGE TOUR'' visits tattoo and body piercing shops, emporiums for magic potions, leather collars and whips, and an estimable French fry place. Meets today at 7 p.m. at the cube at Astor Place, St. Marks Place and Lafayette Street. Led by Michael Kaback. Fee: $15, plus cost of snacks. Information: (212) 370-4214.

''JAZZ NIGHTS IN HARLEM.'' A tour of the area, followed by dinner and a stop at a jazz club. Meets tonight and tomorrow at 8 on the northeast corner of Lenox Avenue and 125th Street. Fee: $45. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Reservations: (212) 280-7888.

''THE FLATIRON DISTRICT: MADISON SQUARE PARK AND ENVIRONS,'' Manhattan. An architectural and historical tour that includes statuary. Meets today at 11 a.m. at the northwest corner of Park Avenue South and 23rd Street. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Fee, $10; $8 for students, the elderly and Society members. Reservations and information: (212) 935-3960.

''THE KENNEDYS AND ROOSEVELTS,'' Upper East Side. A historical walk past sites associated with the two political families. Tomorrow and Sunday at noon. Fee: $12. Sponsored by NYC Discovery Tours. Reservations and meeting place: (212) 465-3331.

''WALL STREET AREA TOUR: MONEY AND OTHER EVILS.'' Covers the titans of the financial world as well as those who challenged them. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. on the steps of the National Museum of the American Indian, 1 Bowling Green. Fee, $10. Sponsored by Radical Walking Tours. Information: (718) 492-0069.

WALKING TOUR OF JAMAICA, Queens. An architectural look at the former farmland led by Barry Lewis, a historian. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. at the King Manor Museum, King Park, Jamaica Avenue, between 150th and 153rd Streets. Sponsored by the museum and the Jamaica Business District. Fee: $5; $2 for children. Information: (718) 206-0545.

''THE GREAT BROOKLYN BRIDGE AND FULTON FERRY LANDING.'' A walk over, under and around the famous structure. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. on the east side of City Hall in Manhattan, opposite the bridge. Sponsored by the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment. Fee, $8; $6 for members; $5 for students and the elderly. Information: (718) 788-8500, extension 401.

CONEY ISLAND, Brooklyn. A pre-season look at the historic summer retreat, led by Kevin Baker, author of ''Dreamland.'' Meets tomorrow at 2 p.m. at Nathan's, 1310 Surf Avenue. Sponsored by the Brooklyn Historical Society. Fee: $10; $5 for members. Information: (718) 254-9830.

HUDSON RIVER TO SOUTH FERRY. A hike of about three and one-half miles along the Hudson River from 23rd Street to the World Financial Center. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. at the Hudson River and 23rd Street. Fee, $3. Sponsored by the Outdoors Club. Information: (212) 877-0743.

''BROOKLYN BRIDGE BIRTHDAY BASH'' features a stroll across the bridge and into Brooklyn Heights. Tomorrow at 2:30 and 5:30 p.m. and Sunday at 2:30 P.M. Fee, $12. Sponsored by NYC Discovery Tours. Reservations and meeting place: (212) 465-3331.

''CELEBRATE THE OPENING OF THE BROOKLYN BRIDGE TALK AND WALK.'' Discusses the building of the Brooklyn Bridge, followed by a walk across and back. Meets tomorrow at 6 p.m. and Sunday at 2 p.m. in Blimpie's Restaurant, 38 Park Row, Lower Manhattan. Fee: $12. Sponsored by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888) 377-4455.

''CHILD-FRIENDLY RAMBLE: CHINATOWN FOR CHILDREN.'' Stops on this tour include a Buddhist temple and a Chinese grocery store. Meets tomorrow at 12:30 p.m. on the northwest corner of the Bowery and Canal Street at the Petrella newstand. Fee: $6. Sponsored by Dr. Phil's New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888) 377-4455.

''HISTORIC HARLEM.'' Emphasizes the history, architecture and residents of what is often considered the center of African-American culture. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. at the Schomburg Center, northwest corner of Lenox Avenue and 135th Street. Fee: $10; students and the elderly, $8. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Information: (212) 439-1090.

''AMBLE THROUGH THE RAMBLE.'' A nature walk through 37 acres of man-made forest, complete with a brook, songbirds and turtles. Meets tomorrow at 11 A.M. at Belvedere Castle, by Turtle Pond and the Delacorte Theater, south of 81st Street. Free. Sponsored by the Central Park Conservancy. Information: (212) 772-0210.

''HIGHLIGHTS OF TRIBECA THEN AND NOW: AN OVERVIEW.'' Tours historic sites including the Woolworth Building and the firehouse used in the film ''Ghostbusters.'' Sunday at 11:45 a.m. and 2:15 p.m. Fee: $11. Sponsored by Gotham Walk. Information and meeting place: (212) 629-1886.

''A DICKENS OF A TIME: CHARLES DICKENS AND NEW YORK CITY IN 1842,'' Lower Manhattan. Covers the squalid sites that he wrote about, including the Five Points slum, the Tombs and a notorious brewery. Sunday at 2 p.m. Led by Michael Emyrs, an urban historian. Fee, $15. Sponsored by Cooper Union. Information: (212) 353-4195.

''HIKE NEW YORK CITY,'' a six- to eight-mile hike of Manhattan, Midtown and downtown, with commentary on its history and folklore. Meets tomorrow at 10 a.m. at the visitors' entrance to the United Nations, First Avenue and 45th Street. Fee: $25 plus refreshments. Led by Michael Kaback. Information: (212) 370-4214.

''THE NEW MEAT MARKET: BUTCHERS, BIKERS AND HIP SCENEMAKERS,'' Manhattan, covers the history of the area from its industrial beginnings to its cultural present. Meets Sunday at 1 P.M. at the entrance to Jackson Square Park, Eighth Avenue and 13th Street. Fee, $12. Sponsored by Joyce Gold History Tours of New York. Information: (212) 242-5762.

SUTTON-BEEKMAN PLACE-TURTLE BAY: ''FROM BETTER TO BEST'' explores the Manhattan neighborhoods of the rich and famous. Meets Sunday at 2 p.m. on the northeast corner of First Avenue and 59th Street. Fee, $10. Sponsored by Bernie's New York. Information: (718) 655-1883.

''THE MYSTIQUE OF GRAMERCY PARK.'' Focus on the history, architecture and famous past residents of this East Side neighborhood. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. on the southeast corner of Broadway and 20th Street. Fee: $10. Sponsored by I'll Take Manhattan Walking Tours. Information: (732) 270-5277.
HARLEM GOSPEL TOUR. Meets Sundays at 10 a.m. on the southwest corner of Lenox Avenue and 116th Street. Fee: $20. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Information: (212) 280-7888.

''SOHO AND LITTLE ITALY.'' The history and architecture of these neighborhoods. Meets Sunday at 2 p.m. at the northeast corner of Broadway and Houston Street. Fee: $10. Sponsored by New York City Cultural Walking Tours. Information: (212) 979-2388.
RECREATION

YOU GOTTA HAVE PARK! AND KIDS GOTTA HAVE PARK, TOO!, Prospect Park, Brooklyn. A five-mile run that begins tomorrow at 10 a.m. on the East Lake Drive. A race for youngsters 2 to 14 years old begins at 9 a.m., also at the East Lake Drive. Sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club. Advance registration fee, $17; $12 for club members; $10 for junior and senior club members. Race day registration, $22, $15 for members; $12 for junior and senior members. Registration for the kids' run, $4, $2 for club members. Information: (212) 860-4555.

AIDS WALK NEW YORK, Central Park. A sign-in begins Sunday at 8:30 a.m. at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street; the walk begins at 10:30 a.m. in the Sheep Meadow, reachable from Central Park West and 67th Street. Sponsored by the Gay Men's Health Crisis. Information: (212) 807-9255.

JAMAICA 5K RUN/3K WALK, Queens. Begins tomorrow at 9 a.m. at 90th Avenue and 160th Street. Registration fee: $20; free for runners under 18. Sponsored by the Jamaica Y.M.C.A. Information: (718) 739-6600.
